description.narrative: Article 19's (A19) strategy operates under the same vision and mission as defined by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights: "Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right include freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers." Through its new strategy for 2015-2020, Article 19 intends to focus its work on five main themes:1) Freedom of expression and information on the Internet - work on defending inclusion of human rights within the digital sphere and bridging the gap between human rights and digital actors.2) Media freedom, pluralism and public interest - work to strengthen the role of civil society, media and activists to advocate for improved media pluralism, freedom and accountability.3) Fight against impunity and protection of those defending human rights - work to improve the security conditions and protection tools and mechanisms for journalists, media workers, human rights defenders, bloggers and othersengaged in defending human rights and fighting against corruption.4) Protection and promotion of civic space - work towards promotion, protection and expansion of civic space, providing legal policy and practical measures and assistance to protect the rights of human rights defenders toassociate, publicly participate, protest and dissent offline and online.5) Development and transparency - work on advocating for better legislation and implementation of access to information laws as well as effective use of those laws by civil society, mainstream right to information principles inthe development agenda with a focus on enhancing public participation of marginalised and vulnerable communities.

description.narrative: Some highlights from the agreement period: A19 made several significant achievements in the area of incorporating the right to information, free expression and association into global, regional and national agreements. A19 together with other CSOs has played an instrumental role in driving the adoption of Latin America and the Caribbean's first legally binding environmental agreement - the Escazu Treaty - ensuring that measures to protect and prevent attacks against human rights defenders on environmental issues were included. A19 also progressed in advocating for the Escazu treaty in Latin America to include strong provisions on access to information, participation and justice in environmental matters. The agreement took nearly six years to negotiate and it has the status of law in the countries which have ratified it. A19 has made significant progress within the field of internet governance, management and standards. A19 has been working with mainstreaming of human rights issues into internet governance bodies. In May 2016, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) officially committed to respect human rights in its institutional bylaws. Since then, A19 has been working extensively with operationalising this decision as chair of the Human Rights working subgroup and continues to work with ICANN to fully operationalise the bylaw and ensure it is reflected in future policy development. This is a significant step towards accountability for ICANN's human rights impacts and the broader mainstreaming of human rights in Internet governance. Within the area of protection, specific progress has been made on safety of journalists. Between 2006 and the end of 2016, 930 journalists were killed for their work, with a 90% impunity rate for those crimes. In 2016, the UN Human Rights Council (HRC) adopted a ground-breaking Resolution on the Safety of Journalists (A/HRC/33/2), the culmination of more than five years work and advocacy by A19 and our partners. On paper, the resolution was the most ambitious ever global agenda on the safety of journalists: A19’s advocacy and recommendations to States led to the adoption of the resolution by all 47 HRC members by consensus, and subsequent sponsorship by more than 90 other States. Media regulation: To address the issue of content regulation on social media platforms, a key issue in 2017-18, A19 proposed a model for “Social Media Councils (SMC)” based on the self-regulatory press-council models. This approach has been endorsed by the UN Special Rapporteur on FoE David Kaye in his report and has become one of the flagship initiatives for the next stage of the delivery on A19:s strategic plan - the XPA Agenda - in the coming years.
